Title.0: Attack Uses Fake Google Docs Application to Access Gmail Accounts
Title.1: Myanmar Denies Involvement in Hack of Journalists' Google Gmail Accounts
Title.2: Phished Gmail Accounts Immediately Accessed by Hackers
Title.3: Gmail Flags Unauthenticated Messages, Dangerous URLs
Title.4: New Kedi RAT Uses Gmail to Exfiltrate Data
Title.5: Students Sue Google over Gmail Account Scanning
Title.8: Google to Soon Kill SSLv3, RC4 Support in Gmail
Title.9: Google Stops Scanning Gmail Content for Ad Targeting
Title.10: Indian Government Wakes up to Risk of Hotmail, Gmail
Title.11: Google Boosts Security For GMail and Google Talk With OAuth 2.0
Title.12: Google's DLP for Gmail Adds Optical Character Recognition
Title.13: Google Launches Data Loss Prevention (DLP) for Gmail
Title.14: Gmail Drops Support for Chrome on Windows XP and Vista
Title.15: Google Gmail App for iOS Doesn't Perform Certificate Pinning: Researchers
Title.16: Google Rolls Out Business-Focused Security Enhancements for Gmail
Title.17: Gmail Delivers Spoofed Messages Without Warning, Researchers Find
Title.18: Gmail to Block JavaScript File Attachments
Title.19: Google Enhances Security Alerts in Gmail
Title.20: Gmail to Warn When Messages Take Unencrypted Routes
Title.21: Gmail Blocking Suspicious Addresses Containing Non-Latin Characters
Title.22: Google Boosts Security of Gmail Infrastructure
Title.23: Undisclosed Glitch Disrupts Gmail for Two Hours
Title.24: Google Reports Huge Drop in Hacked Gmail Accounts

Intro.0: A new attack targeting Gmail users involves a fake Google Docs application.
Intro.1: The Myanmar government denies responsibility for a hack targeting both foreign and local journalists.  [Read More]
Intro.2: Gmail phishing attack: cybercriminals use cleverly designed URLs and they immediately access the hacked accounts  [Read More]
Intro.3: Gmail is now alerting Android users whenever they receive a message that can’t be authenticated with either Sender Policy Framework (SPF) or DKIM.  [Read More]
Intro.4: Kedi RAT is a newly discovered remote access Trojan (RAT) capable of evading security scanners communicates with its command and control (C&C) server via Gmail.  [Read More]
Intro.5: A group of former and current students have sued Google in federal court in San Jose, California, alleging that the company scanned their Gmail accounts and gathered data for advertising purposes.  [Read More]
Intro.6: Mohammad Reza Miri, a member of the telecommunications ministry in Iran, said a recent Gmail block was an "involuntary" consequence of trying to reinforce censorship of Google's YouTube video-sharing site.  [Read More]
Intro.7: Iran blocked access to Google's popular and relatively secure Gmail service Monday amid first steps by the Islamic republic to establish a walled-off national intranet separate from the worldwide Internet.  [Read More]
Intro.8: Starting on June 16, 2016, the old SSLv3 and RC4 security protocols will no longer be supported on Google’s SMTP servers and on Gmail’s web servers.  [Read More]
Intro.9: Google on Friday announced plans to stop scanning the content of consumer Gmail addresses for personalizing the ads it serves to users.  [Read More]
Intro.10: India has begun drawing up a new email policy to help secure government communications, but the man responsible for drafting the rules still regularly uses Hotmail.  [Read More]
Intro.11: Google announced that IMAP/SMTP and XMPP would be getting a security boost in the form of OAuth 2.0. The transition comes as the company depreciates older standards (OAuth 1.0a) on the GMail and Google Talk services.  [Read More]
Intro.12: DLP for Gmail now includes Optical Character Recognition (OCR) for improved attachment scanning, a new set of predefined content detectors, and increased control over content detection thresholds.  [Read More]
Intro.13: Google this week announced Data Loss Prevention (DLP) for Gmail, designed to help Google Apps for Work customers keep their sensitive information secure.  [Read More]
Intro.14: Gmail will soon drop support for Chrome version 53 and below, a move expected to hit Windows XP and Vista users the most.  [Read More]
Intro.15: Researchers at Lacoon Mobile Security discuss an issue impacting the Gmail application for iOS they believe could help an attacker launching man-in-the-middle attacks.  [Read More]
Intro.16: Google today announced a series of improvements to Gmail’s security aimed at making the service better at protecting business data.  [Read More]
Intro.17: Spoofed emails could easily land in user’s Gmail inboxes without even warning them of suspicious activity, security researchers have discovered.  [Read More]
Intro.18: Google announced that JavaScript (.js) file attachments will be blocked by Gmail starting with February 13 for security reasons  [Read More]
Intro.19: Google is boosting the security of its Gmail service in an effort to keep them protected from phishing attacks, malware, and other threats.  [Read More]
Intro.20: Google plans to ramp up security for Gmail by letting users know when messages arrive via unencrypted connections that could be prone to snooping or tampering.  [Read More]
Intro.21: Google has updated Gmail spam filters to block out emails coming from addresses using suspicious combinations of Latin and non-Latin characters, the company said on Tuesday.  [Read More]
Intro.22: Google announced that its Gmail service would use added encryption to protect against eavesdropping and keep messages secure.  [Read More]
Intro.23: Google suffered disruptions on several of its cloud-based services including Gmail for about two hours Wednesday for reasons that were not disclosed.  [Read More]
Intro.24: In a blog post on the company’s war against scams and spam, Google announced on Tuesday that they’ve worked-up a method that is stopping nearly all of the attacks aimed at Gmail account holders.  [Read More]
